title: UN agency runs out of food aid in Gaza after Israeli blockade
snippets: The UN agency has delivered its last supplies to meals kitchens, which it warns will run out of food in the coming days.
titles: UN agency runs out of food aid in Gaza after Israeli blockade
constructiveness_reason: This story clearly highlights the impact of geopolitical decisions on humanitarian aid, providing readers with a deeper understanding of the situation in Gaza and the consequences of the Israeli blockade.
summary: The United Nations agency has completed its final delivery of supplies to meal kitchens, issuing a warning that these facilities will deplete their food resources in the near future.

title: Ukraine may have to temporarily give up land for peace, Kyiv Mayor Klitschko tells BBC
snippets: Vitali Klitschko tells the BBC that although unfair, it could be a temporary solution to end the fighting.
titles: Ukraine may have to temporarily give up land for peace, Kyiv Mayor Klitschko tells BBC
constructiveness_reason: This story provides useful insights into the ongoing conflict in Ukraine and potential solutions. It increases clarity around the geopolitical situation and its impacts.
summary: Vitali Klitschko, in an interview with the BBC, acknowledged that while it may be unfair, a temporary solution could be necessary to halt the ongoing fighting. This statement indicates a willingness to consider interim measures to stop the conflict, despite recognizing their potential inequity.

title: Can India really stop river flowing into Pakistan?
snippets: After a deadly militant attack in Kashmir, India suspended a key water treaty with neighbouring Pakistan.
titles: Can India really stop river flowing into Pakistan?
constructiveness_reason: This story provides useful context about the geopolitical and environmental issues between India and Pakistan. However, it doesn't clearly highlight any solutions or progress in addressing these issues.
summary: Following a lethal militant assault in Kashmir, India has halted a crucial water treaty with Pakistan. This action underscores escalating tensions between the two countries after the attack. The current status is that the treaty, which was a significant part of their water-sharing agreement, is now suspended, impacting relations and potentially affecting water distribution between the nations.

title: Six police officers killed in Thailand plane crash
snippets: The small plane hit the water around 100 metres from the shore near a coastal resort.
titles: Six police officers killed in Thailand plane crash
summary: A small plane crashed into the sea approximately 100 meters from the shore near a coastal resort. The current status of the incident, including the condition of any passengers or crew and the cause of the crash, has not been provided in the information available.

title: Senior Russian general killed by car bomb in Moscow
snippets: Authorities confirm the general, Yaroslav Moskalik, was part of the Russian delegation for the 2015 Minsk agreements.
titles: Senior Russian general killed by car bomb in Moscow
summary: Authorities have confirmed that General Yaroslav Moskalik was a member of the Russian delegation involved in the 2015 Minsk agreements. These agreements were aimed at mitigating the conflict in Eastern Ukraine.

title: Biggest remaining needs for the Bucs after round one in the NFL Draft
snippets: The Bucs still have some glaring needs heading into day two of the NFL Draft.
titles: Biggest remaining needs for the Bucs after round one in the NFL Draft
summary: The Tampa Bay Buccaneers are entering the second day of the NFL Draft with several significant needs yet to be addressed. The team's strategy and choices for the upcoming draft rounds remain a focus of attention as they seek to strengthen their roster.

title: WNBA training camps set to open this weekend with Caitlin Clark preparing for Year 2
snippets: A’ja Wilson, Breanna Stewart and Napheesa Collier will be back on the court Sunday to renew their chase of a coveted WNBA championship when training camps open and last year’s rookie sensation Caitlin Clark begins Year 2 in the league.  Stewart and the New York Liberty will be chasing a second straight WNBA title, something Wilson and the Aces did in 2022 and 2023.
titles: WNBA training camps set to open this weekend with Caitlin Clark preparing for Year 2
summary: A'ja Wilson, Breanna Stewart, and Napheesa Collier are set to return to WNBA action as training camps open on Sunday, with their sights set on the championship. Stewart aims for a consecutive title with the New York Liberty, following their victory last year, while Wilson seeks to continue the success of the Aces, who won the championship in both 2022 and 2023. Caitlin Clark also enters her second season in the league, adding to the anticipation of the upcoming season.

title: Packers' Matthew Golden Shares High Praise For Jordan Love
snippets: The rookie wideout shared what impresses him most about Jordan Love after he was drafted.
titles: Packers' Matthew Golden Shares High Praise For Jordan Love
summary: The rookie wide receiver expressed admiration for Jordan Love's abilities following his draft. He highlighted Love's impressive skills, indicating a positive outlook on their future collaboration on the field. The statement suggests a strong potential for teamwork and success between the two athletes.

title: Panthers’ draft shows how much faith they have in Bryce Young
snippets: Even though the Carolina Panthers are in need of defensive help, they went with wide receiver Tetairoa McMillan to provide Bryce Young with another weapon.
titles: Panthers’ draft shows how much faith they have in Bryce Young
summary: The Carolina Panthers, recognizing a need to bolster their defense, chose instead to enhance their offensive capabilities by drafting wide receiver Tetairoa McMillan. This decision aims to provide quarterback Bryce Young with an additional offensive weapon.

title: Deion and Shedeur Sanders are praising God amid NFL draft stress
snippets: Shedeur Sanders will almost certainly hear his name called Friday during the second or third round of the draft.
titles: Deion and Shedeur Sanders are praising God amid NFL draft stress
summary: Shedeur Sanders is widely expected to be selected in either the second or third round of the upcoming draft on Friday. This anticipation suggests a strong consensus among experts and analysts regarding his draft position.

title: Trump claims to have received call from Xi and to have cut ‘200 deals’ on trade
snippets: Beijing says there are no active talks and Washington should ‘stop creating confusion’
titles: Trump claims to have received call from Xi and to have cut ‘200 deals’ on trade
summary: Beijing has stated that there are currently no ongoing discussions with Washington, urging the United States to 'stop creating confusion' regarding the matter. This announcement clarifies the current state of dialogue between the two nations.

title: Tesla Stock Jumps, Extending Gains as US Loosens Self-Driving Car Rules
snippets:
KEY TAKEAWAYS

  • Tesla shares jumped Friday, extending their recent rally after CEO Elon Musk said he would spend more of his time focusing on Tesla, as the Trump administration moved to loosen rules around self-driving cars.
  • The move would benefit Tesla, which has long touted autonomous cars as central to its growth prospects.
  • Musk said during the company's earnings call Tuesday that Tesla expects to be selling fully autonomous rides in Austin, Texas, in June, with that business expanding to other cities this year. 


Tesla (TSLA) shares jumped Friday, extending their recent rally after CEO Elon Musk said he would spend more of his time focusing on Tesla, as the Trump administration moved to loosen rules around self-driving cars.

The stock was up over 6% in recent trading, making it one of the top-performing stocks on the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Friday. (Read Investopedia's live coverage of today's market action here.)

The Trump administration said Thursday it would loosen rules governing autonomous vehicles, in an effort to help U.S. firms compete with Chinese rivals.

“This Administration understands that we’re in a race with China to out-innovate, and the stakes couldn’t be higher,” U.S. Secretary of Transportation Sean P. Duffy said in a release. “As part of DOT's innovation agenda, our new framework will slash red tape and move us closer to a single national standard that spurs innovation and prioritizes safety.”

The move would benefit Tesla, which has long touted autonomous cars as central to its growth prospects. Musk said during the company's earnings call Tuesday that Tesla expects to be selling fully autonomous rides in Austin, Texas, in June, with that business expanding to other cities this year and becoming financially material in the second half of 2026. 

Tesla shares have been rallying since the call, as investors focused on Musk's pledge to spend more time at Tesla, and the company's plans for a cheaper model and fully self-driving vehicles, rather than its weaker-than-expected results.

With Friday's gains, shares have added about 15% this week. Still, the electric vehicle maker’s stock has lost nearly a third of its value since the start of the year.
titles: Tesla Stock Jumps, Extending Gains as US Loosens Self-Driving Car Rules
summary: Tesla shares surged over 6% on Friday, continuing a recent uptrend after CEO Elon Musk announced plans to dedicate more time to the company. This boost coincided with the Trump administration's decision to relax regulations on self-driving cars, a move expected to favor Tesla's autonomous vehicle ambitions. Musk revealed that Tesla aims to launch fully autonomous rides in Austin, Texas, by June, with plans to expand to other cities within the year. This development, part of Tesla's growth strategy, contributed to the stock's 15% increase over the week, despite a significant drop in value since

title: Google Parent Alphabet’s Stock Climbs as Analysts Raise Targets on AI-Driven Growth
snippets:
Key Takeaways

  • Google parent Alphabet's shares rose Friday following first-quarter results that beat Street expectations.
  • Several analysts raised their price targets for the stock, citing the growth of tools like AI Overviews.
  • Google also "has data and distribution advantages” against generative AI rivals like OpenAI, Bank of America analysts said.


Shares of Google parent Alphabet (GOOGL) climbed Friday as several analysts raised their price targets for the stock after the tech giant delivered better-than-expected quarterly results and touted the early success of AI features.

Alphabet's Class A shares were up close to 3% near $164 in recent trading, propelling it into the ranks of the best-performing stocks on the S&P 500 Friday. (Read Investopedia's live coverage of today's market action here.)

Citi analysts raised their price target to $200 from $195, pointing to growing usage and monetization of AI features in Search, including AI Overviews, which Google said has reached 1.5 billion monthly users roughly a year after launch. “We believe Google’s GenAI search tools are gaining traction,” Citi said. 

Bank of America, which likewise raised its price target to $200, said Google also “has data and distribution advantages” against rivals like ChatGPT developer OpenAI in terms of driving AI usage growth.

Wedbush boosted its target to $200 as well, calling out Google’s growth potential “as investors gain more comfort related to the current macro environment, regulatory risk, and the impact of generative AI on Google Search.”

Meanwhile, Jefferies analysts reiterated a price target of $200, while JPMorgan maintained a target of $195.

CFO Anat Ashkenazi said during the company’s earnings call Thursday that Alphabet still plans to spend $75 billion in capital expenditures this year, most of which is expected to go toward building out the company's AI infrastructure. The investments “should help us have a more resilient organization, irrespective of macroeconomic conditions," Ashkenazi said.
titles: Google Parent Alphabet’s Stock Climbs as Analysts Raise Targets on AI-Driven Growth
summary: Alphabet Inc., the parent company of Google, saw its shares rise nearly 3% to around $164 after reporting first-quarter results that exceeded analysts' expectations, particularly highlighting the success of AI features like AI Overviews. Following these results, several analysts increased their price targets for Alphabet's stock to as high as $200, noting the company's advantages in data and distribution over generative AI competitors such as OpenAI. The company's CFO, Anat Ashkenazi, announced plans to invest $75 billion in capital expenditures this year, focusing on expanding its AI infrastr

title: Top Stock Movers Now: T-Mobile US, Intel, Alphabet, and More
snippets:
Key Takeaways

  • U.S. equities were mixed at midday as the market renewed its focus on the possible impact of new tariffs.
  • T-Mobile US added fewer phone customers than expected, and shares dropped.
  • Alphabet's strong search and advertising growth helped the tech giant to beat profit and sales estimates.


U.S. equities were mixed at midday as the markets continued to weigh the potential impact of tariffs. The Nasdaq gained and the Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 fell.

T-Mobile US (TMUS) shares tumbled after the cellphone service provider added fewer wireless customers than analysts had been looking for. In addition, the CEO warned that customers would have to cover the costs if new tariffs increased phone prices.

Shares of Intel (INTC) declined when the chipmaker gave a disappointing current-quarter outlook, pointing to "elevated uncertainty" in the industry.

Avantor (AVTR) shares sank to their lowest level in five years after the maker of lab chemicals and other life sciences products missed sales estimates, cut its guidance, and announced its CEO was leaving.

Alphabet (GOOGL) shares advanced when the tech giant reported better-than-expected results on solid growth in its search and advertising businesses.

Shares of VeriSign (VRSN) jumped as the internet services provider's sales gained on increasing demand for domain registrations.

Charter Communications (CHTR) shares rose after the cable and internet services firm beat sales estimates and added more mobile line subscribers than anticipated.

Gold futures declined. Oil futures were little changed. The yield on the 10-year Treasury note dropped. The U.S. dollar climbed versus the euro, pound, and yen. Prices for most major cryptocurrencies were higher.
titles: Top Stock Movers Now: T-Mobile US, Intel, Alphabet, and More
summary: U.S. equities showed mixed results amid concerns over new tariffs, affecting various sectors. T-Mobile US saw a drop in shares due to fewer than expected phone customer additions and potential cost impacts from tariffs. Intel's shares fell after providing a disappointing quarterly outlook, citing industry uncertainty. Avantor's shares hit a five-year low following missed sales estimates and a CEO change. Alphabet's shares rose on strong search and advertising growth, beating profit and sales estimates. VeriSign and Charter Communications shares increased due to demand for domain registrations

title: Bitcoin's Upward Move Continues as Trading Week Winds Down
snippets:
Bitcoin was trading at recent highs Friday morning after an upbeat week for stocks. 

The leading cryptocurrency was recently changing hands near $95,000, reflecting a stretch in which investors have shown more appetite for risk assets amid signs of more clarity—and, perhaps, moderation—regarding Trump-administration trade policy. (Hopes of a summer Fed rate cut may also be helping.)

At current prices, bitcoin remains below 2025 highs above $100,000 but has climbed off April lows closer to $76,000. (Read Investopedia’s live coverage of today’s trading here.)

Bitcoin's rise has energized some bitcoin bulls. ARK Invest, for example, this week reiterated its 2030 targets, established earlier this year, for the coin: It's looking for it to rise to a range from around $300,000 to about $1.5 million.

Some crypto-related stocks were also rising Friday as U.S. stocks wavered. Bitcoin buyer Strategy (MSTR), until recently known as MicroStrategy, was up more than 4%. Crypto exchange Coinbase Global (COIN) and miner Marathon Holdings (MARA) were ahead more than 2%. 

And Cantor Equity Partners (CEP), a blank-check company that this week announced plans to become another big holder of bitcoin, extended its upward run, rising some 30% in Friday action. 

The crypto industry also got a lift this week from federal guidance that eased the regulatory burden for banks with crypto offerings.
titles: Bitcoin's Upward Move Continues as Trading Week Winds Down
summary: Bitcoin's value surged to near $95,000 after a week of positive momentum in the stock market, remaining below its 2025 peak but significantly above April's lows. This rise reflects increased investor interest in risk assets, influenced by clearer Trump-administration trade policies and anticipation of a Federal Reserve rate cut. ARK Invest reaffirmed its ambitious 2030 bitcoin price targets, ranging from $300,000 to $1.5 million. Additionally, crypto-related stocks like MicroStrategy, Coinbase Global, Marathon Holdings, and Cantor Equity Partners saw gains, with the latter rising by 30%. The c

title: Hackers could 'vandalise' quantum computers without people noticing
snippets: Hackers may be able to garble the output of programs running on quantum computers, leaving other people with unknowingly incorrect results - but thankfully, there is a fix
titles: Hackers could 'vandalise' quantum computers without people noticing
summary: Researchers have discovered that hackers can manipulate the output of quantum computer programs, potentially providing users with false results. However, a solution to prevent this security vulnerability has been identified, ensuring the integrity of quantum computing outputs.

title: First ever 'black hole bomb' created in the lab
snippets: A black hole bomb - an idea first proposed in 1969 - has now been realised in the lab as a toy model made from a rotating cylinder and magnetic coils. Studying the bomb could help us better understand real black holes.
titles: First ever 'black hole bomb' created in the lab
summary: Scientists have created a laboratory model of a "black hole bomb," a concept first proposed in 1969, using a rotating cylinder and magnetic coils. This model aims to simulate the theoretical behavior of black holes, offering insights into their properties and supporting further understanding of these cosmic phenomena.

title: Ancient camp shows how humans adapted to extreme cold in Europe
snippets: An Austrian site occupied by humans from around 24,000 to 20,000 years ago documents a switch towards hunting reindeer for their fur, which may have helped people to endure harsh winters during the last glacial period
titles: Ancient camp shows how humans adapted to extreme cold in Europe
summary: An archaeological site in Austria has revealed evidence that humans, living there between 24,000 and 20,000 years ago, adapted to harsh glacial winters by increasingly hunting reindeer for their fur. This shift in hunting practices suggests a strategic adaptation to the cold climate of the last glacial period.

title: 'Bone collector' caterpillar wears dead insect body parts as disguise
snippets: A carnivorous caterpillar species camouflages itself with dead insects so it can live safely alongside spiders, stalking their webs and stealing their prey
titles: 'Bone collector' caterpillar wears dead insect body parts as disguise
summary: A carnivorous caterpillar species uses dead insects as camouflage to blend in with spiders' environments, allowing it to safely inhabit spider webs. This unique adaptation not only protects the caterpillar from becoming prey but also enables it to steal food directly from the spiders' webs.

title: Awkward. Humans are still better than AI at reading the room
snippets: Humans are better than current AI models at interpreting social interactions and understanding social dynamics in moving scenes. Researchers believe this is because AI neural networks were inspired by the infrastructure of the part of the brain that processes static images, which is different from the area of the brain that processes dynamic social scenes.
titles: Awkward. Humans are still better than AI at reading the room
summary: Researchers have found that humans outperform current AI models in understanding social interactions and dynamics in moving scenes. This discrepancy is attributed to the design of AI neural networks, which are based on the part of the brain that processes static images, not the area that handles dynamic social scenes.

title: Trump claims to have received call from Xi and to have cut ‘200 deals’ on trade
snippets: Beijing says there are no active talks and Washington should ‘stop creating confusion’
titles: Trump claims to have received call from Xi and to have cut ‘200 deals’ on trade
summary: Beijing has stated that there are currently no ongoing discussions with Washington, urging the United States to 'stop creating confusion' regarding the matter. This announcement clarifies the current state of dialogue between the two nations.

  • T-Mobile US added fewer phone customers than expected, and shares dropped.
  • Alphabet's strong search and advertising growth helped the tech giant to beat profit and sales estimates.


U.S. equities were mixed at midday as the markets continued to weigh the potential impact of tariffs. The Nasdaq gained and the Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 fell.

snippets: An Austrian site occupied by humans from around 24,000 to 20,000 years ago documents a switch towards hunting reindeer for their fur, which may have helped people to endure harsh winters during the last glacial period
titles: Ancient camp shows how humans adapted to extreme cold in Europe
summary: An archaeological site in Austria has revealed evidence that humans, living there between 24,000 and 20,000 years ago, adapted to harsh glacial winters by increasingly hunting reindeer for their fur. This shift in hunting practices suggests a strategic adaptation to the cold climate of the last glacial period.

title: 'Bone collector' caterpillar wears dead insect body parts as disguise
snippets: A carnivorous caterpillar species camouflages itself with dead insects so it can live safely alongside spiders, stalking their webs and stealing their prey
titles: 'Bone collector' caterpillar wears dead insect body parts as disguise
summary: A carnivorous caterpillar species uses dead insects as camouflage to blend in with spiders' environments, allowing it to safely inhabit spider webs. This unique adaptation not only protects the caterpillar from becoming prey but also enables it to steal food directly from the spiders' webs.

title: Awkward. Humans are still better than AI at reading the room
snippets: Humans are better than current AI models at interpreting social interactions and understanding social dynamics in moving scenes. Researchers believe this is because AI neural networks were inspired by the infrastructure of the part of the brain that processes static images, which is different from the area of the brain that processes dynamic social scenes.
titles: Awkward. Humans are still better than AI at reading the room
summary: Researchers have found that humans outperform current AI models in understanding social interactions and dynamics in moving scenes. This discrepancy is attributed to the design of AI neural networks, which are based on the part of the brain that processes static images, not the area that handles dynamic social scenes.

title: Biggest remaining needs for the Bucs after round one in the NFL Draft
snippets: The Bucs still have some glaring needs heading into day two of the NFL Draft.
titles: Biggest remaining needs for the Bucs after round one in the NFL Draft
summary: The Tampa Bay Buccaneers are entering the second day of the NFL Draft with several significant needs yet to be addressed. The team's strategy and choices for the upcoming draft rounds remain a focus of attention as they seek to strengthen their roster.

title: WNBA training camps set to open this weekend with Caitlin Clark preparing for Year 2
snippets: A’ja Wilson, Breanna Stewart and Napheesa Collier will be back on the court Sunday to renew their chase of a coveted WNBA championship when training camps open and last year’s rookie sensation Caitlin Clark begins Year 2 in the league.  Stewart and the New York Liberty will be chasing a second straight WNBA title, something Wilson and the Aces did in 2022 and 2023.
titles: WNBA training camps set to open this weekend with Caitlin Clark preparing for Year 2
summary: A'ja Wilson, Breanna Stewart, and Napheesa Collier are set to return to WNBA action as training camps open on Sunday, with their sights set on the championship. Stewart aims for a consecutive title with the New York Liberty, following their victory last year, while Wilson seeks to continue the success of the Aces, who won the championship in both 2022 and 2023. Caitlin Clark also enters her second season in the league, adding to the anticipation of the upcoming season.

title: Packers' Matthew Golden Shares High Praise For Jordan Love
snippets: The rookie wideout shared what impresses him most about Jordan Love after he was drafted.
titles: Packers' Matthew Golden Shares High Praise For Jordan Love
summary: The rookie wide receiver expressed admiration for Jordan Love's abilities following his draft. He highlighted Love's impressive skills, indicating a positive outlook on their future collaboration on the field. The statement suggests a strong potential for teamwork and success between the two athletes.

title: Panthers’ draft shows how much faith they have in Bryce Young
snippets: Even though the Carolina Panthers are in need of defensive help, they went with wide receiver Tetairoa McMillan to provide Bryce Young with another weapon.
titles: Panthers’ draft shows how much faith they have in Bryce Young
summary: The Carolina Panthers, recognizing a need to bolster their defense, chose instead to enhance their offensive capabilities by drafting wide receiver Tetairoa McMillan. This decision aims to provide quarterback Bryce Young with an additional offensive weapon.

title: Deion and Shedeur Sanders are praising God amid NFL draft stress
snippets: Shedeur Sanders will almost certainly hear his name called Friday during the second or third round of the draft.
titles: Deion and Shedeur Sanders are praising God amid NFL draft stress
summary: Shedeur Sanders is widely expected to be selected in either the second or third round of the upcoming draft on Friday. This anticipation suggests a strong consensus among experts and analysts regarding his draft position.
